stem: The hospital discharge coordinator is discussing placement options with four clients. Based on the documentation in the Transition of Care Inventory, match each client with the most appropriate post-acute facility.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 45y/o following a Spinal Cord Injury (SCI). Stable but requires 3 hours of physical/occupational therapy per day to regain function. 
Patient B: 82y/o following a hip fracture. Recovering well but requires assistance with all ADLs and daily wound care. 
Patient C: 72y/o with terminal pancreatic cancer. Family unable to provide care at home. 
Patient D: 65y/o with mild dementia. Lives alone and has been leaving the stove on; needs a safe environment but no daily medical needs.

tabs.title: Social History
tabs.content: Patient D: Widowed, previously lived in a multi-story home.

rows.text: Intense therapy (3+ hours/day) for a younger patient seeking recovery
Continuous nursing care for wound management and ADLs (Long-term)
End-of-life care for a patient with a prognosis of < 6 months
Supervised residential setting for safety and social needs (No daily nursing)

rationale.correct: Inpatient Rehab (IRF) (c1) requires the patient to tolerate intense therapy (r1). Skilled Nursing (SNF) (c2) provides medical nursing care for those who can't go home yet (r2). Hospice (c3) is for end-of-life (r3). Assisted Living (ALF) (c4) is for residential safety, not medical treatment (r4).

questionTrap.trap: Sending a confused 90-year-old to Inpatient Rehab.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the patient can't tolerate 3 hours of physical work, they belong in a SNF, not an IRF.

mnemonic.title: Facility Logic
mnemonic.expansion: Rehab = Restoring. Skilled = Staying for nursing. Assisted = Advised for safety.
